summary: Santiago Alvarez Rodriguez was a person of interest to the FBI, particularly in relation to Cuban revolutionary matters and potential involvement in anti-Castro activities. An FBI report from 1962 details efforts to gather information on him, including attempts to interview individuals connected to him in Florida. While the FBI Miami office closed its case on him in 1961 due to his inactivity, they noted the CIA's continued interest in his son and yacht. He was also allegedly involved with the 'Esbirros' scandal sheet. He appears in a 1967 FBI report detailing the activities of Manuel Artime and the MRR, a Cuban exile group, suggesting his potential involvement in the anti-Castro movement during the early 1960s.
significance: Based on the provided documents, Santiago Alvarez Rodriguez's significance in the JFK context is indirect. The documents suggest he was involved in anti-Castro activities and was of interest to the FBI and CIA. However, there is no direct evidence in these documents linking him to the JFK assassination. His connections to Cuban exile groups and his monitoring by intelligence agencies could potentially place him within a network of individuals and organizations relevant to understanding the broader context of the assassination, but further investigation would be needed to establish any direct link.
